msDesc.head:
Letter from
Maria Edgeworth
to Madam Miles

editorialDecl.p: Edgeworth’s spelling and punctuation are retained in transcription, except where a word is split at the end of a line and the beginning of the next in a manuscript. The long s and ligatured forms are silently emended.

div.p:
Your very obliging letter & little note
enclosed relieved us all from some
anxiety, as we really began to think, &
not without reason, that we had trespass
edtrespassed too far upon your good nature.

With respect to the muslin for
the frock which I speak of first, because
next my heart, being for my own dear
Fanny - I give up the scheme of working
a border for it because I fear I should not
have it done by the time she might want
it & except for the honor of the business
I have a notion that lace & white satin ribbon
would for a girl of her age look quite as well
- Therefore I leave you quite at liberty as
to the kind & as to the price of the muslin
- all I wish is to have a pretty, dancing dress
of muslin for a girl of 15 & lace to trim it
at bottom - bosom & sleeves - & white satin
ribbon if necessary - As to the price & choice of
the lace I leave the choice to your judgment & taste
& the price to Mr. Eyles's conscience -
My brother Sneyd will take charge of this

muslin & lace, & ribbon & of the veil for me - Probably
you have seen him by this time - He was
suddenly called to London on some business
relative to his wife's affairs.

I am delighted to hear that Mrs. E's lace sleeves
will not be dear as I tempted & indeed
forced her to get them --.
With respect for the Mechlin lace for Honora's
lace frock 4 yds & 3/4 at 8/9 must she thinks
be as much as she wants & she thinks
the price below what she could have hoped.
- I hope it is broad enough for the bottom of
the dress - If this should not be the case
buy a sufficient quantity for trimming the
bottom of her dress of what will suit in general look her broad
lace pattern & I will take the 4 3/4 yds of Mechlin
with pleasure off her hands.

I am tempted to purchase for myself
a pair of sleeves like Mrs. Edgeworth's as you
say they are so cheap & pretty - I have none
that are full as the present mode requires -
I therefore beg you to bespeak me a pair
- My arm is much less than Mrs. Edgeworths
- but as the sleeve draws in, I suppose
an exact pattern is not necessary - I should
not wish mine to be very full as the effect would
be to make me look as broad as I am long
or rather as I am short --
